data.title: Pavel I, Emperor of all the Russias
data.text:
Descendants of Pavel I, Emperor of all the Russias

© John Cilia La Corte 2005

Under the succession laws put in place in 1797 by Emperor Pavel I and added to by his successors, succession to the throne passed by primogeniture to the senior male dynast. Upon the death of the last male dynast of the House of Romanoff-Holstein-Gottorp, the succession would pass to the female line. In order to pass dynastic membership to one’s children, a dynast had to contract an equal marriage with a member of another royal or sovereign house.

In this list all dynasts conforming to these laws bear the surname Romanoff-Holstein-Gottorp. All other direct issue from morganatic marriages either bear the surname of Romanovsky or the double barrelled name of Romanoff combined with the maternal surname.

Grand Duke Vladimir of Russia, as the senior male dynast, was head of the dynasty from 1938 until his death in 1992. By the late 1980s, there survived only five people who by birth were dynasts of the House of Romanoff-Holstein-Gottorp: Grand Duke Vladimir Kirillovich of Russia, Prince Vassily Alexandrovich of Russia and three female dynasts. Upon the deaths of Prince Vassily in 1989 and the Grand Duke Vladimir in 1992, the House of Romanoff-Holstein-Gottorp died out in the male line. The headship of the dynasty then passed, as provided by the succession laws, to the female line: namely, to the Grand Duke Vladimir’s only child, Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna by his equal marriage with Leonida Princess Bagration of Mukhrani, daughter of the Head of the Royal House of Georgia.

Grand Duchess Maria’s heir is her only son by her equal marriage to His Royal Highness Prince Franz-Wilhelm of Prussia who was christened Mikhail Pavlovich when he adopted the Orthodox faith before his marriage. Following the precedent established by Peter of Holstein-Gottorp, her son bears the title of Grand Duke Georgij Mikhailovich of Russia and has taken the dynastic name of Romanoff. He is de jure Tsarevich of Russia.

Further reading:

THE RUSSIAN IMPERIAL SUCCESSION by Brien Purcell Horan, a Juris Doctor and practising lawyer, formerly in charge of the legal section of the United States Embassy in Paris. He is a student of the history and laws of the Russian dynasty, and he served for a number of years, until April 1992, as the late Grand Duke Vladimir’s personal lawyer.

THE RUSSIAN IMPERIAL SUCCESSION – ANOTHER VIEW by Guy Stair Sainty

Part I – Emperors and Heirs Apparent

1. Emperor Pavel I 1 Oct 1754 St Petersburg; 24 Mar 1801 St Petersburg (assassinated) married 7 Oct 1776 St Petersburg Maria Sophia

Dorothea, Duchess of Württemberg 25 Oct 1759 Stettin; 5 Nov 1828 Pavlovsk

2.Emperor Alexander I 12 Dec 1777 St. Petersburg; 1 Dec 1825 married 28 Sep 1793 St. Petersburg Elizabeth

(Luise), Princess of Baden; 24 Jan 1779; 26 May 1826 Bjelev

2. Emperor Nikolai I 25 Jun 1796 Gatshina; 18 Feb 1855 St Petersburg married 1 Jul 1817 St Petersburg Frederica Louise Charlotte

Wilhelmina “Alexandra Feodorovna”, Princess of Prussia;13 Jul 1798 Charlottenburg; 1 Nov 1860 Tsarkoie-Selo

3. Emperor Alexander II 29 Apr 1818 Moscow; 13 Mar 1881 ; St. Petersburg married 28 Apr 1841 St Petersburg Maria Alexandrovna,

Princess of Hesse and the Rhine 8 Aug 1824 Darmstadt ; 9 Jun 1880 St Petersburg at age 55.

4. Emperor Alexander III 10 Mar 1845 St Petersburg; 20 Oct 1894 Livadia married 9 Nov 1866 St. Petersburg Maria Sophia

Frederica Dagmar “Maria Feodorovna”, Princess of Denmark; 26 Nov 1847 Copenhagen; 13 Oct 1928 Copenhagen

5. Emperor Nikolai II 18 May 1868 St Petersburg; 17 Jul 1918 Ekaterinburg (assassinated) married 25 Nov 1894 Victoria Alice

Helena Louise Beatrice “Alix”, Princess of Hesse and the Rhine; 6 Jun 1872 Darmstadt; 17 Jul 1918 Ekaterinburg (assassinated)

5. Emperor Mikhail II [Emperor for 1 day after his brother’s abdication 28.3.1917, abdicated 29.3.1917]; 22 Nov 1878 St Petersburg;

13 Jul 1918 in Perm (assassinated)

4. Grand Duke Vladimir Alexandrovich 22 Apr 1847 St Petersburg; 17 Feb 1909 St Petersburg married 28 Aug 1874 St

Petersburg Marie Alexandrine, Duchess of Mecklenburg-Schwerin; 14 May 1854 Ludwigslust; 6 Sep 1920 Contrexeville, France

5. Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich, Emperor-in-Exile 12 Oct 1876 Tsarskoie-Selo; 13 Oct 1938 Neuilly-sur-Seine married 8 Oct 1905 Tegernsee

Princess Victoria Melita, of Great Britain; 25 Nov 1876 Malta; 2 Mar 1936 Amorbach

6. Grand Duke Vladimir Kirillovich, de jure Emperor Vladimir III Kirillovich 17 Aug 1917 Borga, Finland; 21 Apr 1992 Miami married 13 Aug 1948 Lausanne Princess

Leonida Bagration-Moukhransky, of Georgia; 23 Sep 1913 Tiflis.

7. Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna, de jure Empress Maria I 23 Dec 1953 Madrid married 22 Sep 1976 Madrid Grand Duke Franz Wilhelm

Prince of Prussia, created Grand Duke Mikhail Pavlovich; 3 Sep 1943

8. Grand Duke Georgij Mikhailovich, de jure Tsarevich Georgij 13 Mar 1981 Madrid.
